1.title: Hue
1.text: Hue describes what we typically think of as the color of an object, for instance ''blue'', ''red'', ''purple'' etc. Hue can be represented as a color's position on a standard color wheel. Adding white, black or grey will not change a color's hue.

media.description: The color wheel. Each position represents a different hue.
Different colors with the same hue.

2.title: Hue
2.text: Pure hues are hues without any black, white or grey added. When used sparingly, pure hues can give a playful feel to a composition, or draw the eye in interesting ways.

media.caption: Photograph by Fred Herzog
media.description: The pure red hue in this photograph makes a strong impact when paired with the surrounding muted colors.

media.caption: Cover art for Never Mind the Bollocks here's the Sex Pistols by Sex Pistols
media.description: Pure hues give this album design a fun a playful feel.
media.alt: Cover art for Never Mind the Bollocks here's the Sex Pistols

3.title: Hue
3.text: However, pure hues can easily become overwhelming and unpleasant, especially if they are far apart on the color wheel.

media.description: Too many pure hues can create a clashing effect

media.caption: The Night Cafe by Vincent Van Gogh
media.description: This painting uses bright clashing hues to create an intentionally unsettling effect.
media.alt: The Night Cafe by Vincent Van Gogh

1.title: Shade
1.text: A shade is a hue with black added to it. Colloquially, shade is used to refer to any variance of a hue, but in color terminology shade only refers to variations achieved by adding black.

media.description: Shades of green

2.title: Shade
2.text: When used prominently, shades can create a dark, moody effect

media.caption: Still frame from The Favorite directed by Yorgos Lanthimos
Dos Viejos Comiendo Sopa by Francisco Goya
media.alt: Dos viejos comiendo sopa painting by Francisco Goya

1.title: Tint
1.text: A tint is a hue with white added to it. Tints are often colloquially referred to as ''pastel'' colors.

media.description: Tints of red

2.title: Tint
2.text: When used prominently, tints can create a lighter, brighter feel or a vintage effect, as if the color has faded over time.

media.caption: On the Cliffs by Helen McNicoll.
media.description: The tints in this painting give the sceen a light, calming effect.
media.alt: On the cliffs by Helen McNicoll

media.caption: Cover art for Goodbye Yellow Brick Road by Elton John
media.description: Tints in this album cover design give it a vintage feel.

1.title: Tone
1.text: A tone is a hue with grey added to it. Tones typically appear more dull and muted than pure hues, tints or shades.

media.caption: Frame from the film Victoria
media.description: This frame is entirely composed of tones of the same blue hue.

2.title: Tone
2.text: Adding grey to different hues brings them closer together. Therefore tones can be used to make a color palette more harmonious.

media.caption: Sunrise by Claude Monet
media.description: The bright orange accent color stands out and does not clash against the muted blue tones of the background

1.title: Value
1.text: Value refers to how light/dark a color is. Lighter colors have higher value, darker colors have lower value. For a given hue, shades have lower value and tints have higher value.

media.description: Value scale for blue.

2.title: Value
2.text: Some pure hues have higher value than others. For instance, yellow has a higher value than blue. We can see this by comparing the colors when converted to black and white.

media.description: Pure yellow and blue hues compared to their equivalent greyscale values.
media.alt: Pure yellow and blue and their equivalent greyscale values.

1.title: Chroma/Saturation
1.text: Chroma or saturation refers to how pure a color appears. Adding black, white or grey to a color lowers its chroma. In some contexts, chroma and saturation have slightly different meanings, but for our purposes we will consider them synonyms. Pure hues are the most saturated, while blacks, whites and greys are the least saturated.

media.alt: example of high chroma vs. low chroma

2.title: Chroma/Saturation
2.text: Colors with low chroma appear closer together, even if they have very different hues. Therefore lowering the chroma of a color palette can make it feel more harmonious. However, it can also make it feel more dull and reduce contrast.

media.description: These palettes have the same pure hues.

3.title: Chroma/Saturation
3.text: Kids movies often use highly saturated colors to give a bright, fun energy. Additionally, when paired with moody shades, highly satured colors can create a dark, futuristic city feel.

media.caption: Frame from the film Luca
media.description: Pixar's Luca uses highly saturated colors to give the film a fun, playful aesthetic.

media.caption: Still frame from Blade Runner 2049 directed by Denis Villeneuve.
media.description: Saturated neon colors against a dark background in Blade Runner 2049 set the scene of a futuristic cityscape.
media.alt: Still frame from Blade Runner 2049 directed by Denis Villeneuve

4.title: Chroma/Saturation
4.text: Low saturation/chroma can give a vintage or muted/melancholy feel

media.caption: Cover art for 1989 by Taylor Swift
media.description: Low chroma in the cover art for 1989 helps the image look like a vintage polariod.
media.alt: Cover art for 1989 by Taylor Swift

media.caption: Photograph by Ferran Moya
media.description: The muted colors in this photograph create a gloomy look.

1.title: Contrast
1.text: Contrast is a measure of how distinct colors are . High contrast colors are very different, while low contrast colors are very similar. Contrast can be achieved through both hue and value.

media.caption: Frame from the film The White Ribbon
media.description: An example of high value contrast.
media.alt: Frame from the film The White Ribbon

media.caption: Frame from Pixar's Finding Dory
media.description: An example of high hue contrast. The bright orange and yellow contrast against the blue hues.

2.title: Contrast
2.text: Very high contrast images can create a jarring, striking effect.

media.caption: Frame from the film The Lighthouse
media.alt: Frame from the film The Lighthouse

3.title: Contrast
3.text: Low contrast images can create a hazy feel.

media.caption: Still frame from Blade Runner 2049 directed by Denis Villeneuve.
